ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned to program in C, C++ and MATLAB.
I learned how to write basic coding programs in C, MATLAB, and C++
In learned how to code in c, c++, and matlab.
Sometimes you have to learn by doing
I learned the basics of coding, specifically in the context of C, C++, and MATLAB.

We mostly learned C and we did very very little Matlab and C++ (extremely simple projects that didn't really take advantage of the unique things each program has to offer). I am more comfortable with C now but I definintely could not code anything more complicated than a program with a couple functions and loops.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It does a great job with an intro to computing, I have never programmed before this class and the pace was set well for me to learn and understand the subjects in class and the programming on assignments.
It flowed logically and the ideas were clearly stated.
More coding practice would be helpful

This course was a very nice way to be introduced to coding. I specifically thought that the C++ content was strong and provided lessons I will continue to use past this course. Doc Freeman is a great professor, and he teachers you quite a lot without providing a burdensome workload. The course makes coding feel very natural and fun with the thorough explanations in lectures and fun problem set assignments. The lectures themselves were engaging, and the slides were very in-depth and helpful. I cannot think of any ways the course could be improved.

The class was extremely easy with Prof Freeman. There were barely any psets and tests were open note. This is good if you want a gut, but really bad if you were hoping to learn anything at all. He teaches extremely slow and is pretty disorganized with his lectures. We didn't learn any of the most valuable part of C, like using pointers, and the class is "for engineers and scientists," but we didn't really learn anything that would actually be applicable to engineers and scientists. I wish it was more rigorous.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it, it is a good introduction to programming in 3 languages and is very focused on using programming to solve problems that can come up in engineering.

I would recommend this to people who want to learn the very basics of programming and solve simple problems with code. This class is fairly undemanding in terms of workload so it may be a good place to start if you feel intimidated by the concept of programming and need a place to start.
Yes, it was super manageable and provided a good starting point. It's a confidence boost.
Yhup, it's a useful skill and you still learn things, you just need to practice more outside of class.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is a nice way to be introduced to coding without being overwhelmed by workload and amount of information. I feel like I learned how to code properly on the base level, and I am happy to have taken that away from this class. Doc Freeman is also a great guy, and he makes it very clear what you will be tested on. He has a wealth of information from his diverse working experiences and truly makes lectures entertaining and engaging. The course was one of the more fun ones I have taken at Yale.
If you want to learn any actual coding, take a CPSC class. Or take this class with another professor. This was very disorganized.
